content.question: Which of the following observations provides the best evidence that acetyl-<math alttext="Co A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>CoA</mtext></mrow></math> negatively regulates pyruvate dehydrogenase activity?

choices.label: The rate of the pyruvate dehydrogenase–catalyzed reaction is slower in the presence of a higher concentration of acetyl-<math alttext="Co A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>CoA</mtext></mrow></math>.
The gene that encodes pyruvate dehydrogenase is transcribed when excess acetyl-<math alttext="Co A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>CoA</mtext></mrow></math> is detected.

The accumulation of acetyl-<math alttext="Co A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>CoA</mtext></mrow></math> stops after <math alttext="70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>70</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds, regardless of the reaction mixture.
Acetyl-<math alttext="Co A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>CoA</mtext></mrow></math> is continuously broken down in the Krebs cycle.

content.answer: The rate of the pyruvate dehydrogenase–catalyzed reaction is slower in the presence of a higher concentration of acetyl-<math alttext="Co A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>CoA</mtext></mrow></math>.
